what: Multiple Fill and Colour Scales in ggplot2
title: Multiple Fill and Colour Scales in ggplot2
text: ggnewscale tries make painless use multiple scales ggplot2. Although originally intended use colour fill, work aes, shape, linetype rest. ggnewscale: spend 400% time tweaking ggplot! another way defining multiple scales, can also try relayer.

code: citation("ggnewscale") #> To cite ggnewscale in publications use: #>  #>   Campitelli E (????). _ggnewscale: Multiple Fill and Colour Scales in #>   'ggplot2'_. doi:10.5281/zenodo.2543762 #>   <https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.2543762>, R package version #>   0.4.9.9000. #>  #> A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is #>  #>   @Manual{R-ggnewscale, #>     title = {ggnewscale: Multiple Fill and Colour Scales in 'ggplot2'}, #>     author = {Elio Campitelli}, #>     note = {R package version 0.4.9.9000}, #>     doi = {10.5281/zenodo.2543762}, #>   } knitr::write_bib(c("ggnewscale"), "packages.bib")

title: Multiple Fill and Colour Scales in ggplot2
text: main function new_scale() aliases new_scale_color() new_scale_fill(). added plot, every geom added use different scale. example, let’s overlay measurements contour map topography using beloved volcano.  want create new scales aes, can call new_scale name aes. example, use add multiple linetype scales.
code: library(ggplot2) library(ggnewscale) # Equivalent to melt(volcano) topography <- expand.grid(x = 1:nrow(volcano),                           y = 1:ncol(volcano)) topography$z <- c(volcano)  # point measurements of something at a few locations set.seed(42) measurements <- data.frame(x = runif(30, 1, 80),                            y = runif(30, 1, 60),                            thing = rnorm(30))  ggplot(mapping = aes(x, y)) +   geom_contour(data = topography, aes(z = z, color = stat(level))) +   # Color scale for topography   scale_color_viridis_c(option = "D") +   # geoms below will use another color scale   new_scale_color() +   geom_point(data = measurements, size = 3, aes(color = thing)) +   # Color scale applied to geoms added after new_scale_color()   scale_color_viridis_c(option = "A") #> Warning: `stat(level)` was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `after_stat(level)` instead. #> This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated. new_scale("linetype")

what: ggnewscale: Multiple Fill and Colour Scales in 'ggplot2' — ggnewscale-package

text: Use multiple fill colour scales 'ggplot2'.

text: one colour fill scale plot using ggplot2, add new scale slot new_scale following geoms use different scale previous ones.

title: ggnewscale: Multiple Fill and Colour Scales in 'ggplot2' — ggnewscale-package

what: Adds a new scale to a plot — new_scale
title: Adds a new scale to a plot — new_scale
text: Creates new scale "slot". Geoms added plot function use new scale definition.

title: Adds a new scale to a plot — new_scale
Adds a new scale to a plot — new_scale
text: new_aes string name aesthetic new scale created.

title: Adds a new scale to a plot — new_scale
text: new_scale_color(), new_scale_colour() new_scale_fill() just aliases new_scale("color"), etc...

title: Adds a new scale to a plot — new_scale
code: library(ggplot2)  # Equivalent to melt(volcano), but we don't want to depend on reshape2 topography <- expand.grid(x = 1:nrow(volcano),                           y = 1:ncol(volcano)) topography$z <- c(volcano)  # point measurements of something at a few locations measurements <- data.frame(x = runif(30, 1, 80),                            y = runif(30, 1, 60),                            thing = rnorm(30))  ggplot(mapping = aes(x, y)) +   geom_contour(data = topography, aes(z = z, color = stat(level))) +   # Color scale for topography   scale_color_viridis_c(option = "D") +   # geoms below will use another color scale   new_scale_color() +   geom_point(data = measurements, size = 3, aes(color = thing)) +   # Color scale applied to geoms added after new_scale_color()   scale_color_viridis_c(option = "A") #> Warning: `stat(level)` was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `after_stat(level)` instead.
